p.s: In the given extract from Romeo and Juliet, written by William Shakespeare, the two main characters, Romeo and Juliet, meet again at Juliet's balcony and talk about their forbidden love.
To underline their love and it'sits meaning, the author uses many stylistic devices.
The first metaphor can be found in line 58f, where Juliet says My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tongue's utterance, yet I know the sound.
With this, she refers to their first and only other meeting at the masquearade ball, where they talked for only a few minutes, before getting torn apart.

By saying drunk instead of heard the Authorauthor implies that RomeosRomeo's words are as essential to Juliet as drinking water, while also showcasing, that in contrast to listening to someone, which can be exhausting or even annoying, listening to Romeo is a pleasant experience, like drinking water.
This shows the intensity of their love, despite them only having met each other once.
The next metaphor can be found in Romeo's answer to how he got over the walls (l. 66) where he states, that With love's light wings did I o'erperch these walls.
By saying this, Romeo talks about how he got over the walls, surrondingsurrounding the Capulet's mansion.
With love's light wings he speaks about how his love for Juliet gives him strength and also makes every challenge seem small compared to the ultimate goal of love.
Another way of interpreting this would be, that his love puts him in higher spirits, which makes him never lose hope however hard the challenge might be.
Another time this gets stressed is Romeo saying Stony limits cannot hold love out(l. 67) in wichwhich he is not only talking about the walls, but about everything physical.
The Authorauthor implies that no challenge and no hurt, how bad they might be, could stop Romeo from loving Juliet.
By saying Look thou but sweet, and I am proof against their enmity Romeo brings up the family feud between his family and Juliet's.
He states, that his love is stronger than the hate, that has been going on for decades, even centuries.
This makes him seem indpendantindependent from his family and again stresses his love and his willingness to do everything, to fulfill this love.
Next, Romeo states, that My life were better ended by their hate, than death prorouged, wanting of thy love(ll. 77f).

With this, he says, that he'd rather be killed, than live without his love returned by Juliet, his life would be so pointless, that it would make more sense to die for the family feud so his life fulfilled something, even if it's as useless as the family feud.
Also Juliet states, that I'll provem ore true than those that have more cunning to be strange.
withWith this she refers to the fmaily feud and those, who might see an actual point in it.
She says, that her love is stronger than even the most hateful of the families.
With this, she shows the strength of her love and her willingness to live it.
In conclusion one can say, that both Romeo and Juliet, are ready to love the other one, despite their families.
